Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Testing High Temperature Subseafloor Tracers and Optical Communication Networks at Axial Seamount Using Deep Submergence Vehicle Alvin
Award.AbstractNarration:
This RAPID project involves two different components. The first component relates to a novel, high-temperature glass material which is being developed for future use as a subsurface fluid flow tracer. The second component further develops a new approach to high-speed underwater sensing and wireless communications networks. Both project components are ambitious experiments that progress the NSF mission by providing foundational engineering research with the long-term potential to transform our approach to ocean science, education and policy.

The goal of the first component is to test the stability of a new type of non-toxic, chemically-inert fluorescent glass in hydrothermal vent fluid. If the material can withstand the complex chemical environment of high-temperature vent fluid for an extended duration, it could potentially be used as a tracer for mapping subsurface fluid flow in the future. Such tracer studies will help to address some of the most difficult but fundamental questions we have about the Earth, including: How deep within the Earth does life live? What limits the growth of life in these extreme environments? How large is the subseafloor biosphere, and what role does it play in the carbon cycle? We will test this inert non-toxic material by attaching it to temperature probes and placing the probes in direct contact with high-temperature hydrothermal fluid for 2-3 weeks. We will examine the material before and after vent fluid exposure using fluorescence microscopy, and evaluate any changes in its physical and optical properties.

The goal of the second component is to characterize the range and stability of an optical multi hop sensor network. Sensor networks employ a spatially distributed array of communicating nodes, in which each node collects and transmits data to its neighbors in a web-like fashion. Sensor networks allow scientists to monitor dynamic phenomena over an extended area simultaneously. Optical multi-hop networks will form an important part of the communication backbone for distributed, underwater sensor data collection to help monitor ocean fine-scale phenomena. Such networks can be joined by passing ROVs, AUVs, or other sensors (like those used to monitor the tracers described above) to relay data to each other or onto a cabled observatory or surface buoy for real-time reporting. On this cruise, we will test two optical modem modules deployed multiple times at varying distances apart along a cable. The data will be statistically combined in order to model and plan for future sensor network missions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved two-components, the first was to develop and test a novel fluorescent tracer system for measuring subseafloor fluid flow and the second, related project was to test a wireless optical communication and sensor network. Both components of this project have the potential to transform our approach to ocean science.

The first component forwards a new technology that will ultimately be used to study one of the most notoriously challenging and inaccessible regions our planet – below the crust of the ocean floor. This deep subsurface environment plays host to an ecosystem thought to contain a significant portion of the Earth’s entire biomass. High-temperature fluorescent tracers might one day be able to help us map this deep habitable zone in a variety of environments, including mid-ocean ridges, rifted margins, methane seeps, or terrestrial hydrothermal systems. By knowing where and when such tracers are released into the subsurface and mapping their appearance in the water we can infer a picture of the subsurface flow. Furthermore, if the tracers can be designed to have specific melt temperatures we can determine the maximum temperature the tracers were exposed to during their movement through the porous subsurface. This long-term project is a high-risk high-reward endeavor that will require a layered, multi-disciplinary collaborative approach to develop many new technologies including the tracers themselves, the method of their delivery, and the technology to detect and report their presence. In this first phase, a series of high-temperature fluorescent tracers were synthesized with variable melt temperatures and tested in hydrothermal vent fluid. Although the optical tracers for this project were designed for high temperature stability and specific melt temperatures, they dissolved extremely rapidly in under 30 minutes making them unsuitable for the anticipated transit through the subsurface as they are ultimately intended. Building on the results of this project, new materials are currently under development that should be able to fluoresce brightly yet still withstand the extreme temperature and acidity of hydrothermal fluid.

The second component of this project forwards the development of underwater wireless networked sensor technology. In many situations there is significant benefit to using light to communicate underwater over the typical acoustic approach.  For example, such optical modems might be used to detect and report the tracers described in the first component of this project. In general, underwater optical communications networks address the ocean science community’s need to communicate using low-power and at high speeds, interfacing with existing infrastructure such as deployed sensors or moorings and to other mobile or floating platforms. Through this project we have characterized a pair of underwater optical modems in order to validate multi-hop communications algorithms as a means to extend their effective coverage and to open up new possibilities in ocean sensing and communication.
